physical_appearance:The image shows a black-and-white photograph. It is rectangular and it features a man sitting down. His legs are crossed and he is looking towards the direction where the photograph was captured. He is holding a cane in his left hand and his hat is placed on the ground to the right of the photograph. There is a flower vase on a rised platform to his left as well.

sgcool_label_text:This carte de visite shows John Mather seated on a mother-of-pearl chair with a cane and his hat at his feet. The studio mark ‘Quan Seng’ is printed on the back of the carte. \r\n\r\nStudios were already established across the Strait Settlements and the Dutch East Indies by the 1840s and became increasingly prevalent in the 1850s. During the 1920s
 Chinese-owned studios dominated the studio photography trade in Southeast Asia.

metadata.sgcool_label_text:
This carte de visite shows John Mather seated on a mother-of-pearl chair with a cane and his hat at his feet. The studio mark ‘Quan Seng’ is printed on the back of the carte. 

Studios were already established across the Strait Settlements and the Dutch East Indies by the 1840s and became increasingly prevalent in the 1850s. During the 1920s, Chinese-owned studios dominated the studio photography trade in Southeast Asia.
